review_title: Some good SW experience, but it was time to leave for a real SW career
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Stable company, good benefits, its actually pretty cool to take the Intel Air Shuttle for career/customer meetings, there are good depts out there at Intel to work at. 

I worked in Storage, NAND/Optane storage, and it was a very good experience- the dept ran like it's own company, lots of opportunity, esp in Linux SW design projects. At one point the storage dept was projected to ship more silicon than Intel's CPUs which is crazy.
cons:
red tape, tech growth a little muddled, IT laptop support still all Windows (hello, macOS and Linux laptops anyone), there are bad depts out there to make u miserable.

The storage dept got relocated to the Aloha campus, which is a campus where basically engineering growth (esp SW) dies because lets face it- the Jones Farm, Hawthorne Farm and Rhonler Acres is where all the RandD is happening and you are on your your own forgotten island at Aloha (Intel's first Oregon building).

Also, at the end of the day, if you really want a modern career in SW, you'll need to leave the company. Intel is not a SW company though there is SW work; however  it's really hard to find the latest and greatest SW opportunities at Intel. I started realizing the danger of me becoming obsolete in the SW industry when I attended a few external conferences.  I was also severely underpaid as a SW design engineer and had to get a few external offers (one I obviously eventually took) to prove to management what I thought I was worth was true, especially since I was doing the role of 1.5-2 heads (design + QA).

review_title: 15 years ago, Intel was a wonderful place to work.  But that is no longer the case.
pros:
Very safety oriented
Good medical benefits
Free beverages and fruit in employee cafeterias
cons:
Cut profit sharing contributions to employee 401k from 12.5% of annual salary to 5%.

When reduced 401k contributions began to trigger employee eligibility for the Intel minimum pension plan, Intel froze the pension plan for current employees and got rid of it for new hires.

Cut the maximum contribution employees could make to the employee discounted stock purchase program from 10% to 5%.
 
For over a decade, has made small changes each year or two to the method of calculating employee bonuses and profit sharing.  Each change has been very small, but the net effect over the years has been to reduce the amount of annual bonuses by a significant amount.

To save money, Intel stopped allowing employees working holidays (Christmas, Thanksgiving, Labor Day, Memorial Day, 4th of July, New Year's Day etc.) to claim "Holiday Worked" on their electronic time card, meaning pay for working a holiday that used to be paid at time and a half is now paid at straight time.
 
Intel refers to its pay and benefits package as "T-Comp" or Total Compensation.  Basic pay is designed to be  around the middle of the pack or lower than what you make at other companies.  In bad years, this keeps payroll costs to the company low, and in good years is supposed to allow employees to share in the profits they helped create.  But 2014 was one of the best year in the companies history, yet benefits were cut again.

job_title: Hazardous Waste Technician in Queen Creek, AZ
pros: Intel has great benefits and take care of current employees as long as nothing bad happens to you.  It is a very modern and fast paced environment.  Intel is very involved in their local communities with many volunteer events for employees to take part.  All in all my 29.5 years at Intel were mostly good.  Full of opportunities to learn new things.  I had some GREAT supervisors and some not so great supervisors during my time there.  The good ones were AWESOME and the not so good ones just made life difficult.  I am proud to say I retired from Intel.
cons: Very fast paced and sometimes safety can be an issue.  Due to changes and staffing cuts some departments were cut to bare minimum. In my opinion, for some jobs it was not a safe move.  Be careful out there.  If something happens to you even at no fault of your own and you can't go back to work you are very much ON YOUR OWN.  It took a long time to get to a decent pay grade.  I was quiet and I worked HARD and didn't toot my own horn for MANY years. Finally,  I got a supervisor that saw what I was doing and had been doing for many, many years and brought me up to where I should have been.  Working at Intel can be VERY STRESSFUL as it is a cutting edge technology company.  However, there a lots of AWESOME programs in place for current employees.

job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel is one of the best companies to work in the semiconductor industry. 
Strong brand. Enjoys a very wide competitive moat with its x86 product line. The company is trying hard to transform from a PC-centric business to
data-centric business, but faces significant headwinds and competition in new markets. Few decent acquisitions in the past with good
margins. Payoff on others remain to be seen.
Great people and work-life balance. Strong technical contributors
in some teams. Great resources to learn from if you are motivated and willing
to put in the effort. Great internal recognition tool. Good work is rewarded.
Amazing quarterly and annual bonus plan. Transparent 
profit sharing. Decent ESPP plan.
cons:
If you are an engineer, your mileage will vary depending on the team and the manager. It is easy to get stuck as a cog in a hundred thousand machine.
In some teams few strong technical contributors do all the
heavy-lift, while others easily slack off. Inefficiency is rarely punished.

Slow decision making at the corporate level, which is slowly, but surely making way into newer acquisitions. Hierarchical corp. structure and deep layers
of middle management, some of whom are non-technical. 
Fair amount of internal politics. Hard to get promoted beyond a grade level which leaves no option other than to look for jobs outside. Average
compensation (esp. in the bay area).  Low on stock rewards and the stock has barely moved up. Inconsistent hiring standards and nepotism in some teams, which often lead to bad hires who eventually rotate to other teams.  Cost-cutting and hiring freeze have become the norm. Some projects are kept floating for the sake of keeping people around.

job_title: Applications Developer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Easy to move around internally. Discounts on core products. Employee stock purchases at a discount.
cons:
Your experience is going to highly matter on your direct manager and what division of the company you are in. I am in IT and I had several managers and they were all pretty bad. Overall very low experience in software development, managers are terrible at managing software projects. They pretend to do "Agile" but in reality most "Agile" projects are run in a waterfall methodology with "Agile" names and they just expect you to work faster because it is "Agile".

Very high "vesting" periods for 401k and company granted stock bonus.
Cash bonuses are small, stock bonuses are a little larger, this sucks because of long stock vesting.

Average age of employees is pretty high. Young people tend to quit after a few years because of very outdated company culture that refuses to move-on from old school values that are hurting the company.

The culture is corporate politics heavy handed. Managers are known to override decisions and advice of senior technical contributors like Principle Engineers.

review_title: A great place for internship and learning
job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: As an intern you can learn a lot of great stuff, which can help you grow technically.  Don't have to deal with politics and people are genuinely nice to you.  They are willing to help you if you ask for help.  They also like to hang out with you and tell you things they would not normally say to other full time employees.  Many technical projects are directly related to graduate school research projects and you can find wonderful results and even pick up a thesis topic at Intel.  You can also do many internships in many different groups and learn many skills that a normal employee won't be able to acquire.
cons: Grad technical interns typcially work fairly long hours and the projects are mostly off the critical path.  You usually do not work with many people and are only responsible for your supervisor.  How good your supervisor is determines how much you can learn in your internship and how good your internship experiences are.   Sometimes your supervisor might be very busy with his/her own project and the planning for you might be a little rought.  This is especially true if you are phd level graduate technical intern.  Then you will have to fight on your own to move the project forward and get a decent review.  The review is also up to the supervisor's preference and some never give the highest review at all.

review_title: More to like than not.  A good place to grow and learn.  It's not always easy at the cutting edge.
job_title: Production Control Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Decent pay, decent benefits, interesting & challenging work.  The illusion of job security.  If you want to work hard, learn a lot and kick ass, you can do well at Intel.  There are a lot of great people here: smart, hard-working, dedicated and visionary.  Thing aren't perfect at Intel, but it's hard to argue with the technological and financial results this company has produced, and Intel's record in contributing to environmental, educational and community causes is impressive.  They keep paying me, I'm still having fun (most days).
cons: It's easy to criticize.  Be prepared to work in an environment where a Darwinian approach to annual reviews prevails.  If you're not amongst the brightest in your class, be prepared to live in the middle of the bell curve, if you're lucky.  Sometimes management has a hard time facing and/or telling the truth to themselves and the employees; it sometimes seems they are so wrapped up in marketing spin they can't see reality.  There is atyrannical regime in control of the Oregon development groups that is difficult if not impossible to work with, and embodies the worst arrogance that Intel is known for in the larger marketplace.  If you let it, Intel will take over your life.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
The relocation program is top notch, there is flexibility to take cash, or get the relocation company to take care of everything, or somewhere in between. I opted for the most cash. The really nice thing is that they "Gross Up" the relocation bonus, meaning if you qualify for $5000 in moving bonus, they pay you enough to Net $5000.  They also offer help buying and selling homes. 
I have also enjoyed working with my sub-team and shift Group leader.  The cost for medical/dental is second to none.  I understand that each facility is slightly different but They have on-site gym, massage therapists, doctors, free fruit, free fountain drinks and coffee.  I am impressed with the safety culture, especially as it relates to office ergonomics.  They will get you set up with the ergo equipment that fits you best.  Regular bonuses, a Stock purchase program, and stock award program.  Many paths for career development.  From a business standpoint, I feel that Intel is making really good strategic decisions. I am very happy to work at Intel.
cons: Changes to documentation or procedures can take a long time, Management can be a bit cryptic in "answering" questions or responding to feedback.  I haven't been with the company long enough but, I have heard that the performance review process, which is used to determine raises, promotions, and who stays and who goes during layoffs, is dated and can be hard to navigate.

review_title: Technology giant with shoes tied and eyes blinded.
pros:
For new engineers this is a superb place to work. The work is one of the highest quality in the core competencies. The standards are high, close mentoring is easy to find (if you seek it). The growth can be relatively fast from joining grades to about a level above PhD grade. 

The Oregon campus is actually a notch above other companies' technical campuses. 

The non personnel resources are limitless.
cons:
All happy families are alike but every unhappy family is unhappy in a different way. This applies to various groups at Intel. Some groups lack mandate, some direction, some leadership, some political space and some are back up plans, some are pure ambition of the managers, some are utopian and some dystopian and paranoid. Well that about sums why large parts of Intel underperform despite the pros above esp. With abundant materiel resources.

The absolute tip management lacks confidence and vision. Traditionally stifled innovation in the ecosystem. There are close to nil semiconductor venture funds partly because Intel does not support the ecosystem unlike cisco or apple. Intel is paying dearly for it , cause when the entire industry ran out of options there are no startups to Jumpstart new growth.

review_title: Contracting as Intel Contract Employee Blue Badge
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Salaried, and blue badge workplace benefits such as reduced lunch cost in the cafeteria and free fruit, health care plans, and about half the benefits of an FTE.  Which is way more than Green Badge Contractors get.  Also can work 24 months out of any 36, rather than 18 months out of 24.
cons: NO bonuses, if your hiring manager promised bonuses, he lied.  NO overtime, so if you were used to doing overtime as a green badge, forget it.  You'll still do the overtime, but as a salaried employee you will not be paid for it.  And don't let them tell you it is 24 month out of any 30 either, many hiring managers do not understand contracting, you'll lose out and have to take a full year away from Intel.  Intel does NOT respect talent and ICE is not a path to FTE.  They also use contractors to underpay talent- on average a contract at Intel is $10-$20/hr below market rate for upper scale employees.

review_title: Process and equipment engineer in Kiryat Gat
job_title: Process and Equipment Engineer In Kiryat Gat in Qiryat Gat
pros: Good benefits, quarterly bonuses, yearly bonuses, health insurance, overall salary is about 30% higher than what's stated.
cons:
You have to know that you will work overtime every day.
You leave work at 17:00 but you have to continue working at home for roughly 1-3 more hours, and it's already portrayed in the salary, so there's no extra pay.
The factory works 24x7, it means you have to give engineering support around the clock, that means working from home on weekends and even during the night. Yep, wake up and open your computer at 02:00 AM, and then again at 04:00 AM happens. This is what an around the clock factory needs. You are never free of work and you have to be available at the company's provided phone and have your company's provided computer with you when you are the "point of contact duty" - about 1-2 days a week.
There is no pay for driving fare. If you're not using the company's transportation, you pay your own gas expenses. The minibus transportation is awful, they've put seats in commercial trucks and it breaks you back during the ride. Some destinations have buses and they are much more comfortable.
Personal promotion is declared to be about performance, but it is mostly given to "yes men" and the ones who are willing to do whatever it takes...
People are constantly worried about their job, the number 1 private conversation subject for all the years I've been working there was whether there's a big employee layout  soon, or not. Worries makes most people become competitive, this generates "job-security" behaviors.

review_title: Lack of support for out of the box thinking, pay equity is not what it seems, too much cost cutting..
pros: You can find some people with similar passions that are willing to support you and push for positive change.
cons:
Employees are not empowered to make decisions, everything is top down (even when the top doesn’t have the knowledge needed to make the decision) which slows down decision making and can lead to poor decisions. Too much time is spent trying to educate management rather than doing the work to make a positive impact.

Intel promotes their pay equity, but pay equity can only exist when the staff is in the right pay grade. Major complaint is that even when proving you are doing the work of the next grade, or possibly two grades, there are consistent excuses as to why you can’t get a promotion, such as there is a “waiting list” and you’re far down on the list, or due to reorg you’re in a new group and need to prove yourself again (even though your job/goals didn’t change). Most of us who discuss these challenges are women, yet Intel supposedly has achieved pay equity and met their diversity goals. If consistently exceeds isn’t going to be considered, why have it?

Cost cutting has slowed innovation, reduced community initiatives and has dramatically slowed the pace of change.

review_title: Some good SW experience, but it was time to leave for a real SW career
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Stable company, good benefits, its actually pretty cool to take the Intel Air Shuttle for career/customer meetings, there are good depts out there at Intel to work at. 

I worked in Storage, NAND/Optane storage, and it was a very good experience- the dept ran like it's own company, lots of opportunity, esp in Linux SW design projects. At one point the storage dept was projected to ship more silicon than Intel's CPUs which is crazy.
cons:
red tape, tech growth a little muddled, IT laptop support still all Windows (hello, macOS and Linux laptops anyone), there are bad depts out there to make u miserable.

The storage dept got relocated to the Aloha campus, which is a campus where basically engineering growth (esp SW) dies because lets face it- the Jones Farm, Hawthorne Farm and Rhonler Acres is where all the RandD is happening and you are on your your own forgotten island at Aloha (Intel's first Oregon building).

Also, at the end of the day, if you really want a modern career in SW, you'll need to leave the company. Intel is not a SW company though there is SW work; however  it's really hard to find the latest and greatest SW opportunities at Intel. I started realizing the danger of me becoming obsolete in the SW industry when I attended a few external conferences.  I was also severely underpaid as a SW design engineer and had to get a few external offers (one I obviously eventually took) to prove to management what I thought I was worth was true, especially since I was doing the role of 1.5-2 heads (design + QA).

pros: Company has been good for many years, but with the new CEO, things have gone downhill for the employees.  Flexible work schedule, good benefits, ok pay, cutting edge technology and processes and many managers are working with their employees try to continue to make them happy.
cons:
CEO is old school (be in the office every day from 8 - 5, employees can't be trusted to do what they need to do and must be micromanaged (even if many of them have been doing it for longer than he's been at Intel or have a Doctorate), wants to replace people who know what they are doing with off shore and new college grad resources.  He recently put in place a new process for defining who will be let go without communicating to the employees or the managers.  Many managers were blind sided by the changes and lost really good employees that they can never bring back in the door (again due to his changes) even if the employee actually was a really good employee without any issues and the management wanted to keep them.   Still using outdated process of forcing managers to meet defined percentiles, rather than allowing managers free reign to define how employees should be ranked.  Believes in giving 'benefits' over salary raises because benefits can vary year to year or be reduced/removed so people are under paid compared to industry standards.

Long hours because you will have to work with other time zones and countries, especially with the management moving everything off shore.

review_title: 15 years ago, Intel was a wonderful place to work.  But that is no longer the case.
pros:
Very safety oriented
Good medical benefits
Free beverages and fruit in employee cafeterias
cons:
Cut profit sharing contributions to employee 401k from 12.5% of annual salary to 5%.

When reduced 401k contributions began to trigger employee eligibility for the Intel minimum pension plan, Intel froze the pension plan for current employees and got rid of it for new hires.

Cut the maximum contribution employees could make to the employee discounted stock purchase program from 10% to 5%.
 
For over a decade, has made small changes each year or two to the method of calculating employee bonuses and profit sharing.  Each change has been very small, but the net effect over the years has been to reduce the amount of annual bonuses by a significant amount.

To save money, Intel stopped allowing employees working holidays (Christmas, Thanksgiving, Labor Day, Memorial Day, 4th of July, New Year's Day etc.) to claim "Holiday Worked" on their electronic time card, meaning pay for working a holiday that used to be paid at time and a half is now paid at straight time.
 
Intel refers to its pay and benefits package as "T-Comp" or Total Compensation.  Basic pay is designed to be  around the middle of the pack or lower than what you make at other companies.  In bad years, this keeps payroll costs to the company low, and in good years is supposed to allow employees to share in the profits they helped create.  But 2014 was one of the best year in the companies history, yet benefits were cut again.

job_title: Hazardous Waste Technician in Queen Creek, AZ
pros: Intel has great benefits and take care of current employees as long as nothing bad happens to you.  It is a very modern and fast paced environment.  Intel is very involved in their local communities with many volunteer events for employees to take part.  All in all my 29.5 years at Intel were mostly good.  Full of opportunities to learn new things.  I had some GREAT supervisors and some not so great supervisors during my time there.  The good ones were AWESOME and the not so good ones just made life difficult.  I am proud to say I retired from Intel.
cons: Very fast paced and sometimes safety can be an issue.  Due to changes and staffing cuts some departments were cut to bare minimum. In my opinion, for some jobs it was not a safe move.  Be careful out there.  If something happens to you even at no fault of your own and you can't go back to work you are very much ON YOUR OWN.  It took a long time to get to a decent pay grade.  I was quiet and I worked HARD and didn't toot my own horn for MANY years. Finally,  I got a supervisor that saw what I was doing and had been doing for many, many years and brought me up to where I should have been.  Working at Intel can be VERY STRESSFUL as it is a cutting edge technology company.  However, there a lots of AWESOME programs in place for current employees.

job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel is one of the best companies to work in the semiconductor industry. 
Strong brand. Enjoys a very wide competitive moat with its x86 product line. The company is trying hard to transform from a PC-centric business to
data-centric business, but faces significant headwinds and competition in new markets. Few decent acquisitions in the past with good
margins. Payoff on others remain to be seen.
Great people and work-life balance. Strong technical contributors
in some teams. Great resources to learn from if you are motivated and willing
to put in the effort. Great internal recognition tool. Good work is rewarded.
Amazing quarterly and annual bonus plan. Transparent 
profit sharing. Decent ESPP plan.
cons:
If you are an engineer, your mileage will vary depending on the team and the manager. It is easy to get stuck as a cog in a hundred thousand machine.
In some teams few strong technical contributors do all the
heavy-lift, while others easily slack off. Inefficiency is rarely punished.

Slow decision making at the corporate level, which is slowly, but surely making way into newer acquisitions. Hierarchical corp. structure and deep layers
of middle management, some of whom are non-technical. 
Fair amount of internal politics. Hard to get promoted beyond a grade level which leaves no option other than to look for jobs outside. Average
compensation (esp. in the bay area).  Low on stock rewards and the stock has barely moved up. Inconsistent hiring standards and nepotism in some teams, which often lead to bad hires who eventually rotate to other teams.  Cost-cutting and hiring freeze have become the norm. Some projects are kept floating for the sake of keeping people around.

review_title: A great place for internship and learning
job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: As an intern you can learn a lot of great stuff, which can help you grow technically.  Don't have to deal with politics and people are genuinely nice to you.  They are willing to help you if you ask for help.  They also like to hang out with you and tell you things they would not normally say to other full time employees.  Many technical projects are directly related to graduate school research projects and you can find wonderful results and even pick up a thesis topic at Intel.  You can also do many internships in many different groups and learn many skills that a normal employee won't be able to acquire.
cons: Grad technical interns typcially work fairly long hours and the projects are mostly off the critical path.  You usually do not work with many people and are only responsible for your supervisor.  How good your supervisor is determines how much you can learn in your internship and how good your internship experiences are.   Sometimes your supervisor might be very busy with his/her own project and the planning for you might be a little rought.  This is especially true if you are phd level graduate technical intern.  Then you will have to fight on your own to move the project forward and get a decent review.  The review is also up to the supervisor's preference and some never give the highest review at all.

review_title: More to like than not.  A good place to grow and learn.  It's not always easy at the cutting edge.
job_title: Production Control Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Decent pay, decent benefits, interesting & challenging work.  The illusion of job security.  If you want to work hard, learn a lot and kick ass, you can do well at Intel.  There are a lot of great people here: smart, hard-working, dedicated and visionary.  Thing aren't perfect at Intel, but it's hard to argue with the technological and financial results this company has produced, and Intel's record in contributing to environmental, educational and community causes is impressive.  They keep paying me, I'm still having fun (most days).
cons: It's easy to criticize.  Be prepared to work in an environment where a Darwinian approach to annual reviews prevails.  If you're not amongst the brightest in your class, be prepared to live in the middle of the bell curve, if you're lucky.  Sometimes management has a hard time facing and/or telling the truth to themselves and the employees; it sometimes seems they are so wrapped up in marketing spin they can't see reality.  There is atyrannical regime in control of the Oregon development groups that is difficult if not impossible to work with, and embodies the worst arrogance that Intel is known for in the larger marketplace.  If you let it, Intel will take over your life.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
The relocation program is top notch, there is flexibility to take cash, or get the relocation company to take care of everything, or somewhere in between. I opted for the most cash. The really nice thing is that they "Gross Up" the relocation bonus, meaning if you qualify for $5000 in moving bonus, they pay you enough to Net $5000.  They also offer help buying and selling homes. 
I have also enjoyed working with my sub-team and shift Group leader.  The cost for medical/dental is second to none.  I understand that each facility is slightly different but They have on-site gym, massage therapists, doctors, free fruit, free fountain drinks and coffee.  I am impressed with the safety culture, especially as it relates to office ergonomics.  They will get you set up with the ergo equipment that fits you best.  Regular bonuses, a Stock purchase program, and stock award program.  Many paths for career development.  From a business standpoint, I feel that Intel is making really good strategic decisions. I am very happy to work at Intel.
cons: Changes to documentation or procedures can take a long time, Management can be a bit cryptic in "answering" questions or responding to feedback.  I haven't been with the company long enough but, I have heard that the performance review process, which is used to determine raises, promotions, and who stays and who goes during layoffs, is dated and can be hard to navigate.

review_title: Technology giant with shoes tied and eyes blinded.
pros:
For new engineers this is a superb place to work. The work is one of the highest quality in the core competencies. The standards are high, close mentoring is easy to find (if you seek it). The growth can be relatively fast from joining grades to about a level above PhD grade. 

The Oregon campus is actually a notch above other companies' technical campuses. 

The non personnel resources are limitless.
cons:
All happy families are alike but every unhappy family is unhappy in a different way. This applies to various groups at Intel. Some groups lack mandate, some direction, some leadership, some political space and some are back up plans, some are pure ambition of the managers, some are utopian and some dystopian and paranoid. Well that about sums why large parts of Intel underperform despite the pros above esp. With abundant materiel resources.

The absolute tip management lacks confidence and vision. Traditionally stifled innovation in the ecosystem. There are close to nil semiconductor venture funds partly because Intel does not support the ecosystem unlike cisco or apple. Intel is paying dearly for it , cause when the entire industry ran out of options there are no startups to Jumpstart new growth.

review_title: Contracting as Intel Contract Employee Blue Badge
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Salaried, and blue badge workplace benefits such as reduced lunch cost in the cafeteria and free fruit, health care plans, and about half the benefits of an FTE.  Which is way more than Green Badge Contractors get.  Also can work 24 months out of any 36, rather than 18 months out of 24.
cons: NO bonuses, if your hiring manager promised bonuses, he lied.  NO overtime, so if you were used to doing overtime as a green badge, forget it.  You'll still do the overtime, but as a salaried employee you will not be paid for it.  And don't let them tell you it is 24 month out of any 30 either, many hiring managers do not understand contracting, you'll lose out and have to take a full year away from Intel.  Intel does NOT respect talent and ICE is not a path to FTE.  They also use contractors to underpay talent- on average a contract at Intel is $10-$20/hr below market rate for upper scale employees.
